The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
California Education Code Section 76355 provides the Board of Trustees the option of increasing the student health services fee by the same percentage as the Implicit Price Deflator for State and Local Government Purchase of Goods and Services.
	 
The District received notification from the California State Chancellor's Office in April 2012 that the index had increased enough since the last fee increase in 2011 to support a $1 increase to the fee.
	 
Fees collected in Fiscal Year 2012-2013 totaled $589,899; however, were not enough to support operations.  The Unrestricted General Fund supported the health services program at Evergreen Valley College by $5,119 and at San Jose City College by $32,006.  It is anticipated that the $1 increase will yield approximately $35,000 in additional revenue to support the Student Health Centers.
	 
The proposed fee increase has been vetted through each campus' shared governance process.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Student Health fee increase of $1 per semester to $19 effective Fall 2014.

items.item_details:
Non-resident Tuition Rate:
	 
Education Code Section 76140 requires districts' governing boards to establish the non-resident tuition rate by February 1st for the succeeding year.  Education Code Section 76140 (e) enumerates seven options, which are attached, for a district to choose in establishing the rate.
	 
The District's current non-resident tuition rate is $199 per semester unit.  In FY 2012-2013, the District realized $1,060,952.  In order to retain and attract non-resident students, staff recommends maintaining the rate at $199 per semester unit per Option Five (see attachment).
	 
Capital Outlay Fee:
	 
Education Code Section 76141 allows for a district to charge a capital outlay fee to any non-resident student.  The amount of the fee shall not exceed the amount that was expended per FTES by the District in FY 2012-2013 for capital outlay, calculated at $65.70 per semester unit, and shall not exceed 50% of the FY 2012-2013 non-resident tuition rate, calculated at $99.50 per semester unit.
	 
The District's current capital outlay fee is $4 per semester unit.  In FY 2012-2013, the District realized $12,759.  Staff is recommending maintaining the rate at $4 per semester unit in keeping with the District' retention and attraction strategy.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the non-resident tuition rate of $199 per semester unit and the capital outlay fee of $4 per semester unit for Academic Year 2014-2015.

On September 18, 2013 and September 25, 2013, Bid Proposal #13-1016 - Parking Permit Services for SJECCD was advertised for parking permit and citation services. The bid was developed by the Chief of Police and the Purchasing Department. The RFP went out to eight different vendors for Parking Permit Services and we received seven responses with two proposals having a vendor partnership. The proposals were evaluated by an evaluation committee comprised of a Purchasing Agent, Campus Police staff, the EVC Dean of Enrollment and three ITSS employees. One Vendor was ruled out because they did not address the citation/violations specifications fully, and proposed that many of the requirements were District related responsibilities rather then resolved in conjunction with the vendor. Attached is the list of vendors who participated in the bid, the criteria for which the evaluation was based, and the vendor that is being recommended to the Board.
	 
The recommendation is for a three (3) year award and may be renewed, for a total contract term not to exceed five (5) years to the partnership of Turbo Data Systems, Inc. and Credentials Order Processing Solutions, Inc. Attached is the pricing structure of their services. Turbo Data Systems, Inc. is both a small and a local business.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award the contract of Bid Proposal #13-1016 - Parking Permit Services for SJECCD to Turbo Data Systems, Inc. and Credentials Order Processing Services, Inc.

items.item_details:
On July 10, 2012 the Board approved utilizing the Lease/Leaseback (LLB) project delivery method for EVC South Campus.  On February 12, 2013 the Board approved issuance of a Preconstruction Agreement with Blach Construction as the Lease-Leaseback contractor for the project.  
	 
Additionally, at its July 9, 2013 meeting the Board authorized use of design-assist subcontracting, allowing Blach to enter into competitively-bid subcontracts for specific work in order to bring design and pricing expertise in those trades to the project.  In that action the Board was notified that these subcontracts would carry an early-termination clause that would allow a subcontractor to recoup costs if its contract were cancelled.  Two such design-assist contracts, Royal Glass and B.T. Mancini, were to provide the building’s exterior envelope.
	 
At the completion of the Design Development phase the project was estimated to be approximately $6.5 million over budget.  After extensive effort to bring the project within budget by the entire project team and the College, one major element, the exterior envelope, was identified as carrying significant costs and contingencies because of its design.  To address this the exterior envelope configuration was simplified, and while the involvement of Royal and Mancini was critical to identifying the problem and developing alternative solutions, the normalizing of the exterior design eliminates the need for further special exterior envelope design assistance.  Additionally it is anticipated that the simpler design will make the project more attractive to a broader subcontractor base and provide stronger bids for the work.  It is for these reasons that the project team recommends directing termination of the design-assist contracts for Royal Glass and B.T. Mancini.
	 
The Board is asked to approve a Change Order to Blach’s Preconstruction Agreement in the amount of $102,254 to compensate the exterior envelope design-assist subcontractors for the cost of services they provided to substantiate estimates, initiate shop drawings and eventually help scale back the design to meet the budget.  Their detailed timesheets and work product have been reviewed by Gilbane, Blach and HMC Architects.  After negotiation the final presented costs are found reasonable for the duration and effort of those subcontracts.  The change order amount includes a 5% mark-up for Blach Construction as detailed in their contract for procurement and coordination efforts with these subcontractors.  (Please note that this approach has been reviewed with legal counsel, and it is their opinion that the Blach Preconstruction Agreement is a professional services agreement, and as such is not subject to the statutory limitations of the Public Contract Code.)
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve a change order 001 to the Blach Construction Preconstruction Agreement for termination of Exterior Envelope Design-Assist Subcontracts for the Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project.

On July 9, 2013 the Board approved a Contract to Swenson & Associates in the amount of $3,165,000 for replacement of the Gullo Student Center’s roof, existing windows, corrugated metal siding, fiber cement panels and to install below-grade waterproofing to ensure a watertight building.  The work also includes changes to the building required by the Division of State Architect.
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order #002 includes deletion of two sidewalks, added horizontal soffit panels, addition of waterproofing material to exterior panel supports, new LED exterior light fixtures, revisions to exhaust fan and walkway flashing, changing metal flashing to prefinished material, window support and waterproofing flashing details, and panel revisions to retain architectural appearance at existing wall conditions.  
	 
This Change Order also includes a sixty (60) day no-cost time extension to the contract substantial completion date from January 10, 2014 to March 11, 2014.  The overall construction duration was delayed due to unforeseen window opening dimension variations, metal panel layout, structural support and color selection modifications, and added exterior soffits which required additional procurement time.  
Swenson & Associates submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include additional or deleted materials, equipment, labor, time extensions as applicable and the prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.

On July 9, 2013 the Board approved a Contract to Swenson & Associates in the amount of $3,165,000 for replacement of the Gullo Student Center’s roof, existing windows, corrugated metal siding, fiber cement panels and to install below-grade waterproofing to ensure a watertight building.  The work also includes changes to the building required by the Division of State Architect.
	 
During the period of time since the Gullo Student Center was constructed, interior finishes such as painted walls, exposed structural supports, handrails, and door/window frames have worn and are currently in need of repainting.  Original building carpeting has reached the end of its useful life, and needs replacement with more durable and easily cleaned material.  The wood flooring on the second floor also requires refinishing and sealing to extend the wearable duration of the material.   
	 
At the request of the College, Swenson & Associates submitted written pricing proposals for changes that includes materials, equipment, labor and the prescribed mark-ups for refreshing painting and replacement of flooring.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.

Revised Contract Amount                  $3,424,630
	 
The net change to Swenson and Associates contract as a result of all changes issued is $259,630, which equates to 8.20% of the base contract.

items.item_details:
On August 24, 2013, the Board of Trustees held a Special Governing Board Meeting in which they received training on the Carver Policy Governance Model. The training was provided by Miriam Carver, Carver Consulting. Ms. Carver provided an overview of the principles of board governance and leadership, differentiation between the roles of the college board and the chief executive officer, the board's accountability to their "constituents, " (defined as the  840,000  voters in the seven trustee district service areas,)  evaluation of the chief executive officer and the board itself, how to maintain board discipline, differentiation between policy and management, and many other such relevant topics.
After the training, the board discussed its desire to use the Carver Policy Governance Model as its approach for providing governance and leadership for the district and the need to declare their intent at their next meeting; including a discussion of the preparatory steps leading to the adoption of the model.
	 
As part of the next steps process for moving forward with the Carver Policy Governance Model, then Board President Mayra Cruz introduced the concept at both colleges during the August 29, 2013, PDD. President Cruz informed district members that they would receive training on this model, which would be scheduled at a future date before the end of the calendar year. At the September 10, 2013, governing board meeting, the Board took action to initiate a process to explore the adoption of the Carver Policy Governance Model. Therefore, President Cruz requested that Chancellor Cepeda move forward with the next steps in providing further training for the board and district members. Chancellor Cepeda provided information on the model to the district's constituency group leaders at the September 16, 2013, District Council meeting. At that meeting, DVD's of the Carver Policy Governance Model were provided to constituency groups so that they could share this information with their respective constituencies during their regularly scheduled group meetings. Further information and training was provided for constituency group leaders by Ms. Carver on December 9, 2013, and December 12, 2013, at the District Office. The Board itself received training on the development of policies using the Carver Policy Governance Model at its regularly scheduled meeting on December 10, 2013, and at two special governing board meetings held on December 11 and December 13, 2013. After the special meeting held on December 13, the majority of the board expressed interest in moving forward with adopting the Carver Policy Governance Model.
	 
It is, therefore, recommended that the Board of Trustees sunshine their expectation to adopt the Carver Policy Governance Model as its model of governance and leadership.

The California Community College Trustees (CCCT) board serves a major role within the Community College League of California. Meeting five times a year, the twenty-one member board provides leadership and direction to ensure a strong voice for locally elected governing board members.
	 
From January 1 through February 15, nominations for membership on the CCCT board will be accepted in the League office. Nominations are to be made by member district board of trustees; and each district may nominate only members of its board. Each nominee must be a local community college district trustee, other than a student trustee, and must have consented to be nominated. Only one trustee per district may serve on the board.
	 
The attached CCCT 2014 Board Election packet contains the official nomination form, biographical sketch form, and statement of candidacy forms to be submitted with the nomination packet. 
	 
This nomination packet is being provided to the SJECCD Board of Trustees for information. If any member of the board is interested in being nominated to the CCCT Board, it is requested that they inform President Lease of their interest.
